title: Current state of Edmonton amateur football scene is unhealthy
text:
Report an error 
At first, the note from U of A communications leader Matt Gutsch was encouraging. He told the media that Golden Bears have a reasonable chance of qualifying for Canada West playoffs. 
But the good feeling faded about as fast as it had arrived, as soon as a picture of Edmonton’s overall football success (or failure) took shape. 
The hard-working Gutsch’s second note corrected earlier word that the Golden Bears had missed the Canada West university football playoffs. 
Riding a five-game losing streak in which they surrendered 244 points, the initial report caused no tsunami of surprise. 
Now it’s important to remember that the Bears earned a tie-breaker edge on the Saskatchewan Huskies for the final playoff spot thanks to a 38-26 victory in the second game of the year. 
Right now, Alberta and the Huskies have identical 2-and-5 records. Even more feeble are the winless Regina Rams, who have locked up last place and will be a major element in the in-or-out ultimate decision. 
Saskatchewan must be considered the favourite in that Canada West Turtle Derby. The Rams haven’t been able to beat their own shadows. 
If the Huskies win, or even if they lose, they’re in, barring a miracle. A few weeks ago, the Bears were whacked 80-18 by the Calgary Dinos, who visit Foote Field Saturday for what used to be a good old-fashioned Edmonton-Calgary hoedown. 
I can’t imagine Alberta turning that verdict upside down. Can you? 
For me, the worst of it is this: Golden Bears failure is compounded by the dismal status of both the Edmonton Huskies and Wildcats in the Prairie Junior Football Conference. 
And the fact that both junior teams missed the playoffs and were rarely contenders in any game, is compounded by the reality that Calgary’s high school teams have been superior to Edmonton’s in recent seasons and there is a strong likelihood that it will be the same again when provincial titles go on the agenda in November. 
There must be a way of clearing up this mess. 
Junior football guys who blame Golden Bears coach Chris Morris – and there are many – refuse to deal with the reality that junior coaching, especially among assistants, is often inexperienced and, more often, simply inept. 
At the high school level, it is become necessary for many schools to find coaches apart from their own staffs. Those so-called outsiders, willing to put up the time and effort necessary to build or recreate good programs, often lack daily and weekly in-class opportunities that regular teachers find so beneficial. 
Don’t ask me why, but I’m convinced nothing will change until the Bears and the junior operators come to a common goal in terms of recruiting and sharing information. 
Until then, those who care about Edmonton football can only wait, fingers crossed. Current state of Edmonton amateur football scene is unhealthy By John Short , Edmonton Sun First posted: Sunday, October 25, 2015 07:18 PM MDT | Updated: Sunday, October 25, 2015 07:27 PM MDT
